utterances: And I also would like to caution him.
Get too many retirees in your town, like we have in Grants Pass, and you have a heck of a hard time floating a school bond initiative.
A lot of the seniors just don't want to pay any taxes.
Oh, so there's the downside.
We hadn't thought about that.
I mean, the upside is that they don't need schools, so you don't have to build so many classrooms and hire teachers.
On the other hand--had you thought about that?
Is that a consideration, Ken?
I mean, is there this downside before we get a comment from...
Yeah, there is.
By the way, I've been to Tyler.
You know, it got hit by the oil boom a few decades ago and now it's perhaps a great place for people to consider relocating.
But Malcolm is also right.

If you're--if any population becomes too heavily concentrated with older people, you run the risk of becoming a kind of a `gerassic park,' G-E-R-A-S-S-I-C, where all of a sudden the older people just take over and often and unfortunately they tend to vote away from school programs, they vote away from certain kinds of infrastructure which then could cause the community to lose some of its appeal to younger families.
Multigenerationality is really what it ought to be, not just one or the other.
Tom, is that something that worries you?
Yeah.
It's a common issue that comes up.
And let me make two points.
One is we don't want to become just a retirement community.
I think I said that a minute ago that we want them to become a part of the community and we're going to be retirement-friendly.
But we don't want that to be the dominant makeup of our economy.

Secondly--excuse me, about 15 years ago, Texas A&M did an interesting study with Texas, Arkansas and Mississippi retirees that had relocated within the last couple of years, and they found out that people that are willing to relocate from where they've been for decades to a new retirement location tend to be higher income, higher education; a lot of them are younger retirees.
And when they get to a community, they like to get involved.
And when asked the question, `If you've been there for at least two years and have you had a chance to vote on a school bond issue, how did you vote?
a strong majority of them voted to support the school bond issue.
And what we found out is that the people who tend to be against growth and against schools and taxes are the people who never left town.
Aha.
That's an interesting way.
That's very interesting.
Thank you for your call, Malcolm.
That's very interesting.
What's the deal with the humidity in Tyler?
Well, at this time of the year, it's very low.
OK.
OK.
So that might be my second home then if I could--hey, tell me about this now.
I understand Tyler is about to become the first certified retirement community in Texas.
Tell me about that.
What does that mean?
We put that program together ourselves.

We looked at other states; Tennessee and Mississippi have a program at a state level where they'll certify communities after they meet a certain list of criteria that would be attractive to retirees, you know, like the list I read earlier, and then maintain that and have a point of contact and really work hard to take care of the issues and questions and needs of retirees.

We put that program together on a regional basis here about five years ago and then just this last legislative session, the state Legislature has now implemented a statewide certification program for retirees.
So I think you'll see more cities in Texas going after the designation.
All right, Tom.
Well, thank you very much.
Well, thanks for having me.
I appreciate it.
Tom Mullins is president and CEO of the Tyler Area Chamber of Commerce and joins us from his office in Tyler, Texas.
We're taking your calls this hour as we talk about how the baby boomers are retiring and just how attractive they are to cities like Tyler and others around the country.
Doug is on the line from Dayton, Ohio.
Hi, Doug.
How you doing?
Good.
Got a question for us?
Yeah.
Hey, I was wondering, you know, most of them people ain't retiring to Florida anymore because probably Florida's filled up, you know.
The working people like me, we just can't afford to go...
Yeah.
...(unintelligible).
Talking about Tyler, Texas, and all that, I mean, you know, common man can't go there.
I mean, it's just too overpriced.
So you're saying that not everybody's--well, are you planning to move?
(Laughs) No, I can't afford to move.
You know, where am I going to go?
Like I said, Florida was the only place a retired man could go and now it's filled up.
All right.
Talking about Tyler, Texas, talking about the schools and this and that--you know what?
Seriously, I mean, my taxes are ridiculous.
You know, my kids are grown, I'm getting ready to retire in three years and it--I mean, it's just out of hand.
All right.
How these people can top that, I don't even know because, I mean, I don't--they must live in another world or something, I mean, 'cause it ain't like that here.
Let's see if we can get the numbers and thank you for the call.
What percentage of the--I guess a couple of questions.
Do we have an idea of what percentage of baby boomers really are going to move and can afford to?
Fifty-nine percent of the boomers are planning on moving either right around the time of retirement or right after, which is a pretty high number.
And...
Well, how does it compare with previous generations?
It's higher.
Yeah.
This is a generation that's moved when they went to college or maybe their jobs caused them to relocate.
They're more mobile, more comfortable.
And by the way, thanks to the Internet and, frankly, even programs like NPR, you can hear about possibilities.
And by the way, Doug, I would tell you, that Doug is kind of right.
That there are three or four regions of the country that in the past 20 years have become Meccas for retirement lifestyles--Florida, Arizona and the Carolinas.
Those are getting pretty expensive.
But there's fantastic other regions in the country to live for people at all levels of income, if you do a little bit of searching.

And more people in the years to come will do more of that, and a lot of these regions are going to start reaching out for you because they'd like your Medicare spend and they'd like your dollar over at the coffee shop and they'd like for you to be paying rent or mortgage payments on your home.
It's only 25 cents 'cause you get the senior discount, the coffee.
I hear senior discounts are going to go away, by the way.
Sorry about that.
Bob sends us an e-mail.
Says, `My wife and I play music on the side in a small college town, San Luis Obispo, California, and as soon as the kids are in college, we are going to tour.
We have albums that get modest air play on public and independent radio stations around the world, and I expect boomers will enjoy live music as much as they did back in the '60s and '70s.'
Absolutely.
You know, Cream reunited and sold out Madison Square Garden.
As I said, Rolling Stones is still touring.
Last year, Destiny Child's tour had a--shut down because it wasn't selling seats, but The Eagles sold out.
The idea--two points that Bob mentions.
Number one, maybe you've got a love or a hobby that you've just been too busy for and you just can't wait to jump into it when you become an empty-nester or a retiree.
And, second, there's a lot of people going to have a lot of free time to fill up with movies and theater and poetry and dancing and volunteerism and charitable works.
And I also think a lot of boomers are going to try to make the transition from a success to significance, from leisure to legacy.
It's not just a matter of `What can we do that would be kind of fun and games?
but `How can we take these years of our lives and really make a contribution to our families and our communities?
I think this is some of the flavor you're going to see more of in the years to come.
And if those '60s bands ever stop touring, PBS would go under; fund raising would go down.
But, hey--what were you going to say?
Right.
I think the doo-wop guys are going to live to 100.
I don't know how they do it, but they're still--going pretty good.
Yeah.
They're a credit to our loss of hearing, too.
Listen, does Florida have anything to worry about in all of this?
I mean, the traditional retirement spots, are they going to be hurt?
Yeah.

Strangely enough, what's happened in the last few months, since the weather concerns, is that there are people that are second-thinking whether they should move to Florida and want to wait a few years until the weather settles down.

But I can tell you, I was just in Las Vegas last month and the amount of condos that real estate speculators are buying up now, because of the idea that Florida's market may go softer, is going sky high.
So, you know, one man's unfortunate circumstance is another man or woman's opportunity.
But, yeah, I do think people are a little bit anxious right now, just as people used to be about earthquakes in California.
A little anxious, but I don't think that's necessarily stopping people, but it is causing people to pause.
We are talking today about what happens when baby boomers retire and how anxious cities and states are to have them retire in their communities.

And I'm talking with Ken Dychtwald, who's a gerontologist and CEO of Age Wave, a think tank that looks into these kind of things; also author of ""The Power Years: A User's Guide to the Rest of Your Life.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Frank Stasio.
